etymologies: Middle English: from Old French rene, based on Latin retinere ‘retain’

notes.text: The idiomatic phrase a free rein, which derives from the literal meaning of using reins to control a horse, is sometimes misinterpreted and written as a free reign. More than a third of the citations for the phrase in the Oxford English Corpus use reign instead of rein

definitions: a long, narrow strap attached at one end to a horse's bit, typically used in pairs to guide or check a horse while riding or driving.
shortDefinitions: long, narrow strap attached at one end to horse's bit

definitions: the power to direct and control

examples.text: management is criticized for its unwillingness to let go of the reins of an organization and delegate routine tasks

notes.text: The idiomatic phrase a free rein, which derives from the literal meaning of using reins to control a horse, is sometimes misinterpreted and written as a free reign. More than a third of the citations for the phrase in the Oxford English Corpus use reign instead of rein

definitions: check or guide (a horse) by pulling on its reins

examples.text: he reined in his horse and waited for her

shortDefinitions: check or guide horse by pulling on its reins

examples.text: with an effort, she reined back her impatience
critics noted the failure of the administration to rein in public spending
